awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Using Titanite as a Petrochronometer for Direct Fabric Dating of High Temperature Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Mountain ranges form when the Earth's crust contracts due to the collision of tectonic plates. This contraction generates granite plutons in the crust and deforms those granite plutons through shear zones (localized regions of intense deformation). Both processes imprint a "fabric" on the granite, an arrangement of minerals that records the deformation of the rock. The mineral titanite crystallizes during the formation of granite in the crust and during the formation of rock fabric, and both events can be dated using the radioactive decay of uranium into lead within titanite crystals.  This new method for dating shear zones will be used to examine mountain building processes and the development of rock fabrics that subsequently can control further magma emplacement, faulting, fluid flow, and metal ore mineralization. 

This study will focus on the physical and chemical changes in the mineral titanite during deformation. Structural geology techniques will investigate the physical changes through the outcrop and microscale structures of the rock, and electron microscopy will quantify the recrystallization of individual mineral grains. Chemical changes in titanite will be measured by X-ray and mass spectrometry techniques, and individual crystals will be dated using measurements of uranium-lead isotope ratios. These techniques will be applied in two study areas, in shear zones in western Idaho and east-central California. Rocks from these areas show a wide range of fabric development, from non-deformed to pervasively sheared. The variety of degrees of deformation measured through the methods described above will be used to test how the intensity of a rock fabric develops during shear zone movement. Outcomes in both study areas will include methodologies to establish sub-million year resolution of the timing of deformation, the spatial-temporal pattern of strain accumulation within shear zones, and the feedbacks between magmatism and deformation. This project will more broadly support graduate research training, on-line science learning modules, and geoinformatics database development. Results of this research will be widely disseminated through peer-reviewed journals, professional meetings, data repositories, and websites.

por.por_cntn:
Mountain ranges form when the Earth?s crust contracts due to the collision of tectonic plates. This contraction generates granite plutons (bodies of rock generated at the same time and place with the same composition) and deforms those granite plutons through shear zones (localized regions of intense deformation). Both processes imprint a ?fabric? on the granite, an arrangement of minerals that records the deformation of the rock. The fabric of shear zone rocks we examine today is the final product of deformation, so to understand the processes that leads to that final arrangement of minerals, we developed a method of looking at the mineral titanite to observe snapshots of the deformation process. The mineral titanite crystallizes during granite formation and recrystallizes and newly grows in response to changes in temperature, pressure, and differential stress during deformation, making it an ideal mineral for studying how granite plutons are emplaced into the crust and subsequently deformed. We found that even within only a few cubic centimeters of deformed granite, different titanite crystals preserve different moments of a shear zone?s history.

We can date how shear zones evolve with time using the radioactive decay of uranium into lead within titanite crystals. To expand our understanding of deformation, we use an approach termed ?petrochronology? that uses the geochemical and microstructual context of minerals to interpret their ages and extract information about the sequence of temperature-time-deformation conditions that affected the rock. In this manner, we distinguished between titanite grown at different stages of granite pluton emplacement and deformation by integrating titanite ages, titanite crystal position within the fabric, microscopic images of the interiors of titanite crystals that show the growth history of the crystal, titanite trace element chemistry, and patterns of how titanite crystal structures are internally distorted due to deformation. We used statistical methods to aggregate the numerous trace element signals measurable in titanite and then identify the signals that were most informative in terms of describing how titanite responds to deformation. From this we built interactive, three dimensional geochemical visualizations that allow others to interact with the data and see how we use it in our petrochronology studies. We also developed new techniques for microsampling that allow us to date increasingly small volumes of titanite which minimizes our geologic uncertainty.

Through this work we have been able to describe the sequence of processes that produced deformed rocks we see today in the 15 kilometer wide western Idaho shear zone, Idaho, USA and the 5 kilometer wide Rosy Finch shear zone, Sierra Nevada batholith, California, USA. In the western Idaho shear zone, we intensively studied a highly deformed granite pluton to document how titanite a) crystallized during the initial generation of the pluton, b) recrystallized during the early stages of deformation, c) was newly grown from infiltrating fluids or the breakdown of other minerals within the rock during deformation, and d) finally recrystallized again during the final stages of deformation. We were able to pinpoint a shear zone initiation age of between 99 and 96 million years ago for the western Idaho shear zone. By looking at multiple rock samples spread across the whole shear zone, we traced how the location of intense deformation shifted across the shear zone in space and time, commonly in response to new granite plutons being intruded into the nearby crust. We found that this shear zone persisted for over 25 million years but that deformation was only concentrated in individual locations for a few million years at a time. Similarly, we dated a suite of samples from the Rosy Finch shear zone and found that the sequence of progressive intrusion of sheet-like bodies of granite within the mapped pluton controlled the localization of strain and evolution of the shear zone in this segment of the Sierra Crest shear zone, in this case over less than 2 million years.

This grant has promoted collaborations between scientists in two geoscience subdisciplines, structural geology and geochronology, and promoted the career development of three female graduate students, with two to receive their doctoral degrees. This collaboration allowed us to detail the specific histories of different shear zones and catalog the different ways that deformation behaves from the micro to the macro scale. The method we developed for titanite deformation petrochronology is broadly applicable to other shear zones in areas where tectonic plates contract and deform granite plutons. Knowing the timing and tempo of deformation is critical for reconstructing the evolution of tectonic plate boundaries, their hazards, and their resources.
